Oh, you just mean this?

import Mathlib

instance : CompactIccSpace unitInterval := ‚ü®fun {_ _} => isClosed_Icc.isCompact‚ü©

isClosed_Icc returns a proof, not a proposition (which is a statement). Does this help? Do you understand the difference between {} inputs to functions ("Lean will work this out") and () inputs ("the user must supply these")? Honestly I recommend you read #tpil rather than just trying to work out everything yourself by staring at more complex examples.

The version I came up with from your code was roughly

instance : CompactIccSpace unitInterval := by
  unfold unitInterval
  apply CompactIccSpace.mk'
  intro b
  intro c
  intro d
  apply IsClosed.isCompact
  apply isClosedIcc

-- Auf dem Raum der stetigen Funktionen C([0,1]) ist durch ‚à•f‚à•L1 = R1|f(x)|dx eine Normdefiniert.
-- (Dies brauchen Sie nicht zu zeigen.) Zeigen Sie, dass eine Funktionenfolge (fn) in C([0, 1]),
-- die gleichma Ãà√üig gegen f konvergiert, auch bezu Ãàglich der Norm ‚à• ¬∑ ‚à•L1 gegen f konvergiert.

abbrev C := ContinuousMap unitInterval ‚Ñù

noncomputable
def L1_norm (f : C) : ‚Ñù := ‚à´ x: unitInterval, |f x|

-- Define the L1 space
def L1 := {f : C | L1_norm f ‚â• 0 }

-- Define the uniform convergence
def uniform_convergent (f : ‚Ñï ‚Üí C) (limit : C) := ‚àÄ Œµ : ‚Ñù, Œµ > 0 ‚Üí ‚àÉ N : ‚Ñï, ‚àÄ n : ‚Ñï, n ‚â• N ‚Üí ‚àÄ x : unitInterval, x ‚àà Set.Icc 0 1 ‚Üí |(f n) x - limit x| < Œµ

instance : NormedAddCommGroup ‚Ñù := normedAddCommGroup
-- instance : IsLocallyFiniteMeasure (MeasureTheory.Measure unitInterval) := sorry

instance : CompactIccSpace unitInterval := by
  unfold unitInterval
  apply CompactIccSpace.mk'
  intro b
  intro c
  intro d
  apply IsClosed.isCompact
  apply isClosed_Icc

-- Theorem: If (fn) converges uniformly to f, then it also converges in L1 norm to f.
theorem uniform_convergence_implies_L1_convergence (f : ‚Ñï ‚Üí C) (limit : C) (h_uniform : uniform_convergent f limit) :
  Filter.Tendsto (Œª n => L1_norm (f n)) Filter.atTop (ùìù (L1_norm limit)) := by
    -- We need to show that the L1 norms converge to the L1 norm of the limit
    rw[Metric.tendsto_atTop]
    intros Œµ Œµ_pos
    -- Use the uniform convergence property to find N
    obtain ‚ü®N, hN‚ü© := h_uniform Œµ Œµ_pos
    use N
    intros n hn
    -- Use the definition of the L1 norm
    unfold L1_norm
    have h‚ÇÅ : ‚àÄ x ‚àà Set.Icc 0 1, |(f n - limit) x| ‚â§ Œµ := by
      intros x hx
      specialize hN n hn x hx
      exact (le_of_lt hN)

    -- rw[‚Üê L1.dist_eq_integral_dist]

    -- Apply the Lebesgue Dominated Convergence Theorem
    -- integral_le_integral_of_le
    -- exact integral_le_integral_of_le (ContinuousMap.abs_sub_integral_le _ _ h‚ÇÅ)


    let bound := f n
    let Œº: MeasureTheory.Measure unitInterval := volume




    let hmeas : ‚àÄn, AEStronglyMeasurable (f n) volume := by
      intro ns

    -- show vv

    let hlim : ‚àÄ·µê a ‚àÇŒº, Filter.Tendsto (fun n : ‚Ñï ‚Ü¶ f n a) Filter.atTop (ùìù (limit a))  := sorry
    exact tendsto_integral_of_dominated_convergence bound hmeas hint hbound hlim

According to the infoview, bound is a term of C, that is a real number in the unit intervalEDIT: sorry I misread! What should bound.continuous represent? Lean is confused by the fact that you are supplying this for a proof that a function is continuous.

First step: isolate the thing that goes wrong:

    have := Continuous.integrableOn_Icc (bound.continuous)

If you hover over Continuous.integrableOn_Icc, you can see it requires IsLocallyFiniteMeasure Œº which seems likely to have created the goal that lean has trouble with (IsLocallyFiniteMeasure ?m.7695). What happened here is that lean can't tell what Œº should be. So you can pass it explicitly:

    have := Continuous.integrableOn_Icc (Œº := volume) (bound.continuous)

but this still complains that

failed to synthesize instance
  IsLocallyFiniteMeasure volume

Hovering over volume shows it's the volume for unitInterval. The next thing I'd try is adding

instance : IsLocallyFiniteMeasure (volume (Œ± := unitInterval)) := by
  sorry

and look what happens next. Unfortunately it still can't figure out which Icc you want to talk about, so you can try this:

    have := Continuous.integrableOn_Icc (Œº := volume) (a := 0) (b := 1) (bound.continuous)

which allows you to move forward

  simp only [Set.image_univ, Subtype.range_coe_subtype, ge_iff_le, zero_le_one, not_true, gt_iff_lt, Set.mem_Icc,
